added_lines: Sorting the List ---------------- You can specify the sorting keys and sorting direction when list policies, using the option :option:`--sort` (or :option:`-o`). The :option:`--sort` option accepts a string of format ``key1[:dir1],key2[:dir2],key3[:dir3]``, where the keys used are policy properties and the dirs can be one of ``asc`` and ``desc``. When omitted, Senlin sorts a given key using ``asc`` as the default direction. For example, the following command instructs the :program:`senlin` command line to sort policies using the ``name`` property in descending order:: $ senlin policy-list -o name:desc When sorting the list of policies, you can use one of ``type``, ``name``, ``level``, ``cooldown``, ``created_at`` and ``updated_at``. Paginating the List -------------------

subject: Delete python bytecode before every test run
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-01-10 08:32:30.000000000', 'files': ['tox.ini'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.context/commit/bd775052268763783736c56be508c6ab772d4f7a', 'message': 'Delete python bytecode before every test run

Because python creates pyc|pyo files and __pycache__
directories during tox runs, certain changes in the tree,
like deletes of files, or switching branches, can create
spurious errors.

The target bytecodes for deletion are in normal directories,
but not in dot started directory.

Change-Id: Idd7e51de48864a3fab80e78c27e7942b2ab1d55c
'}]
commit_message:
Delete python bytecode before every test run

Because python creates pyc|pyo files and __pycache__
directories during tox runs, certain changes in the tree,
like deletes of files, or switching branches, can create
spurious errors.

The target bytecodes for deletion are in normal directories,
but not in dot started directory.

Change-Id: Idd7e51de48864a3fab80e78c27e7942b2ab1d55c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.context refs/changes/20/265620/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: commands = find . -type f -name "*.pyc" -delete python setup.py testr --slowest --testr-args='{posargs}'

commit_message:
Replace deprecated [logger/LOG].warn with warning

Python 3 deprecated the logger.warn method, see:
https://docs.python.org/3/library/logging.html#logging.warning, so we
prefer to use warning to avoid DeprecationWarning.

Change-Id: I6b09f67bb63fbdf31903ec175db012fc50e87f16
Closes-Bug: 1508442

commit_message:
config: Add a spec for a oslo.config proxy config opts

Part of blueprint proxy-config-opts

Change-Id: Id78fd96f587871d7697d995cc376e1e9c5ee0c0d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-specs refs/changes/47/130047/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This template should be in ReSTructured text. For help with syntax, see http://sphinx-doc.org/rest.html ============================= The title of your blueprint ============================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo.config/+spec/dictionary-backend-config-opts The current implementation of oslo.config has a ``ConfigOpts`` that is only really useful from an application since it expects a CLI or config files to be found and used to configure itself. This does not work for libraries that do not know (and can not know or predict) how they will be used (they may be referenced from other libraries and not applications...). Problem description =================== The existing oslo.config library is very much connected to configuration files and CLI arguments. Since a large number of oslo libraries depend on oslo.cfg and this style of configuration that makes it very very hard to use those libraries from another library that does not itself provide a API that also exposes ConfigOpts. This makes the usage of ConfigOpts viral, which means that all libraries that use ConfigOpts using libraries must now expose a ConfigOpts themselves so that the final application that uses these libraries can correctly provide the configuration files or CLI arguments to configure all the using libraries. This is not simplistic and does not create for elegant and/or self-contained library API's that do not wish to expose there internals to the outside world (also a bad software design pattern in the first place). This overall makes it very hard to use a library in oslo that has a majority of its API coming from a ``ConfigOpts`` object (for example oslo.messaging). With an ability to have a ``ConfigOpts`` class that doesn't require explicitly tie itself to configuration files and CLI arguments but instead can be provided a dictionary object (or some similar object that provides a ``__getitem__`` method) this means that libraries which would like to use oslo.messaging can instead provide this ``ConfigOpts`` derivative instead (and therefore use those libraries in a way that does not depend on the existing ``ConfigOpts`` style of configuration, this avoids the previously stated problem). Proposed change =============== The current oslo.config code provides a ``ConfigOpts`` class that performs the majority of operations with regards to reading, registering, importing and overriding. This class is also the one responsible for reading from and generation configuration files and/or CLI arguments. This is alot of responsbility that should not be in a single class in the first place (IMHO). The change described here will create a dervivative of ``ConfigOpts`` that will not have the methods to read from configuration files, or arguments but will instead only have the ability to read/write to a provided dictionary (or other object with needed ``__getitem__`` and ``__contains__`` methods) that is given when the new ``ConfigOpts`` subclass is created. The usage of this would be something like:: my_config = { 'kombu_ssl_certfile': 'blah', 'ssl_version': 'blah', } cfg = DictConfigOpts(my_config) # Now pass cfg into all the existing libraries that use ConfigOpts and # there existing reading of configuration and registering (now a no-op) # will continue working as expected... Alternatives ------------ The existing effort seems to be centered around having library APIs that take options from 2 places (which is confusing when used and can become easily inconsistent when applied). One being from a ``ConfigOpts`` instance or one being from a ``URL`` instance. Other libraries provide a more natural second way of configuring the underlying objects by translating the provided ``ConfigOpts`` object into keyword arguments which are then used to create an appropriate database backend. The later approach is fine and will not be discussed here (for oslo.db this has worked out ok, but they do not have the habit of passing around ``ConfigOpts`` instances to many other objects, so this approach was much more feasible for them). This first option (of having dual API's, one from config and one from a URL like object) has at least for oslo.messaging not turned out to be reality as that library still configures 4/5 of its objects, drivers, transports using a passed around ``ConfigOpts`` object and about 1/5 using a passed in URL object. What the 1/5 and what the 4/5 are (and where they overlap) is a effort left up to the reader to try to figure out (it is not easily determinable what that split is and what the overlap is either...). The alternative is to fix the URL object support and maintain 2 apis for all existing objects, drivers, transports in oslo.messaging (this will not be a backwards compatible adjustment in certain places). Another option is to not do anything, and make it very hard to use the libraries like oslo.messaging in libraries that do not have strong ties to ``ConfigOpts`` instances. These general purpose libraries like tooz, or taskflow wish to work (and have been working with) with the surrounding python community (and not just the surrounding openstack community). This means that libraries which wish to work in both communities (which all libraries should strive to do IMHO) are stuck in a rock-and-a-hard place since now they either have to reinvent pieces of the mentioned libraries or change there API to be one that only really works in the openstack community where the usage of ``ConfigOpts`` is prevalent. Those libraries could in theory completely use the ``URL`` object support if it was fully functional and was a true first class citizen (and not a partially implemented second class citizen). Impact on Existing APIs ----------------------- With this change it will not affect existing APIs as the existing APIs will now just be reading from and interacting with (registering options) a ``ConfigOpts`` instance that is not backed by a configuration file or CLI arguments. With the other mentioned alternative (URL objects) there would be a much more dramatic API change for the existing libraries which have strongly tied them-self to usage and passing around of ``ConfigOpts`` instances. Security impact --------------- N/A Performance Impact ------------------ N/A Configuration Impact -------------------- N/A Developer Impact ---------------- This will make it easier to use libraries (oslo.db, oslo.messaging) which have stronger ties to ``ConfigOpts`` instances (and passing them around throughout the library) work with libraries that do not have APIs that themselves pass around ``ConfigOpts`` instances. This gives those libraries which do not have that API the ability to create a dictionary of there own choosing and interact correctly with the libraries which do have the strong tie to ``ConfigOpts`` instances in a mostly seamless manner. Testing Impact -------------- Existing unit tests will be updated. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: harlowja Milestones ---------- K2 Work Items ---------- 1. Split apart ``ConfigOpts`` into a ``_BaseConfigOpts`` class which has the methods that will needed to be shared between the existing ``ConfigOpts`` and the new ``DictConfigOpts`` subclasses (the ``_BaseConfigOpts`` will not have such methods as ``find_file``, ``_parse_config_files``, ``reload_config_files`` or similar which are currently the methods that tie ``ConfigOpts`` tightly to CLI arugments and configuration files). 2. Ensure that the appropriate methods in the ``DictConfigOpts`` are provided and work correctly when ``register_opt`` and friends are called upon (what these methods will actually do at this point is up for discussion). 3. Ensure that for the basic oslo libraries that use the existing ``ConfigOpts`` can be passed in a ``DictConfigOpts`` and still continue operating correctly using a non-config-file/cli provided options... Incubation ========== N/A Documentation Impact ==================== Will need updated oslo.config documentation to describe how to use this new capability. Dependencies ============ N/A References ========== I'm pretty sure I covered enough of the reasoning why this is needed in the above :) .. note:: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode

commit_message:
remove log_console_of_servers from get_remote_client

This is never used by any caller of this function, and just causes
confusion. It also explains where console logs in scenario tests are
not as useful as they could be because we never can scope the console
logs to the guest that failed.

Change-Id: I9ff86a5b1c8c31ad4bb9b86fcda59cfeae954ef2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/13/264313/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def get_remote_client(self, server_or_ip, username=None, private_key=None): self._log_console_output()
deleted_lines: def get_remote_client(self, server_or_ip, username=None, private_key=None, log_console_of_servers=None): @param log_console_of_servers a list of server objects. Each server in the list will have its console printed in the logs in case the SSH connection failed to be established # If we don't explicitly set for which servers we want to # log the console output then all the servers will be logged. # See the definition of _log_console_output() self._log_console_output(log_console_of_servers)

subject: glusterfs/vol layout: remove manila-created vols upon delete_share
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-10-20 08:22:14.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/manila/commit/07bfc26929c50c3e552c65ac95c838cbfabada04', 'message': "glusterfs/vol layout: remove manila-created vols upon delete_share

With volume layout the volume we use to back a share can
be pre-created (part of the volume pool provided for Manila),
or can be created by Manila (that happens if share is created
from snapshot, in which case the volume is obtained by performing
a 'snapshot clone' gluster operation).

In terms of resource management, pre-created volumes are owned
by the pool, and Manila cloned ones are owned by Manila. So
far we kept all the volumes upon giving up its use (ie. deleting
the share it belonged to) -- we only ran a cleanup routine on them.
However, that's appropriate action only for the pool owned ones.
However, the ones we own should rather be extinguished to avoid
a resource leak. This patch implements this practice by marking
Manila owned volumes with a gluster user option.

Closes-Bug: #1506298
Change-Id: I165cc225cb7aca44785ed9ef60f459b8d46af564

commit_message:
glusterfs/vol layout: remove manila-created vols upon delete_share

With volume layout the volume we use to back a share can
be pre-created (part of the volume pool provided for Manila),
or can be created by Manila (that happens if share is created
from snapshot, in which case the volume is obtained by performing
a 'snapshot clone' gluster operation).

In terms of resource management, pre-created volumes are owned
by the pool, and Manila cloned ones are owned by Manila. So
far we kept all the volumes upon giving up its use (ie. deleting
the share it belonged to) -- we only ran a cleanup routine on them.
However, that's appropriate action only for the pool owned ones.
However, the ones we own should rather be extinguished to avoid
a resource leak. This patch implements this practice by marking
Manila owned volumes with a gluster user option.

Closes-Bug: #1506298
Change-Id: I165cc225cb7aca44785ed9ef60f459b8d46af564
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila refs/changes/54/237454/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: USER_CLONED_FROM = 'user.manila-cloned-from' clone_of = gmgr.get_gluster_vol_option(USER_CLONED_FROM) or '' try: if UUID_RE.search(clone_of): # We take responsiblity for the lifecycle # management of those volumes which were # created by us (as snapshot clones) ... args = ('volume', 'delete', gmgr.volume) else: # ... for volumes that come from the pool, we return # them to the pool (after some purification rituals) self._wipe_gluster_vol(gmgr) args = ('volume', 'set', gmgr.volume, USER_MANILA_SHARE, 'NONE') try: gmgr.gluster_call(*args) except exception.ProcessExecutionError as exc: LOG.error(_LE("Gluster command failed: %s"), exc.stderr) raise exception.GlusterfsException( _("gluster %(cmd)s failed on %(vol)s") % {'cmd': ' '.join(args), 'vol': gmgr.qualified}) errdict = snapshot.copy() errdict['err'] = exc.stderr LOG.error(_LE("Error creating share from snapshot " "%(id)s of share %(share_id)s: %(err)s"), errdict) argseq = (('set', [USER_CLONED_FROM, snapshot['share_id']]), ('set', [USER_MANILA_SHARE, share['id']]), ('start', [])) for op, opargs in argseq: args = ['volume', op, gmgr.volume] + opargs try: gmgr.gluster_call(*args) except exception.ProcessExecutionError as exc: errdict = snapshot.copy() errdict['err'] = exc.stderr LOG.error(_LE("Error creating share from snapshot " "%(id)s of share %(share_id)s: %(err)s"), errdict) raise exception.GlusterfsException(_("gluster %s failed") % ' '.join(args))
deleted_lines: try: self._wipe_gluster_vol(gmgr) args = ('volume', 'set', gmgr.volume, USER_MANILA_SHARE, 'NONE') try: gmgr.gluster_call(*args) except exception.ProcessExecutionError: raise exception.GlusterfsException( _("gluster %(cmd)s failed on %(vol)s") % {'cmd': ' '.join(args), 'vol': gmgr.qualified}) LOG.error(_LE("Error creating share from snapshot: %s"), exc.stderr) try: gmgr.gluster_call( 'volume', 'start', gmgr.volume) except exception.ProcessExecutionError as exc: msg = (_("Error starting gluster volume. " "Volume: %(volname)s, Error: %(error)s") % {'volname': gmgr.volume, 'error': exc.stderr}) LOG.error(msg) raise exception.GlusterfsException(msg) args = ('volume', 'set', gmgr.volume, USER_MANILA_SHARE, share['id']) try: gmgr.gluster_call(*args) except exception.ProcessExecutionError: raise exception.GlusterfsException( _("gluster %(cmd)s failed on %(vol)s") % {'cmd': ' '.join(args), 'vol': gmgr.qualified})

commit_message:
Fix delete_snapshot error case in Pure driver

Our previous error handling was incorrect for delete_snapshot. This
adds a check on repsonse and correctly logs only a warning if
required.

Change-Id: Ic73d92eaa5869efe1dc0e56d3156edd7dbcac2e8
Closes-Bug: #1489635

commit_message:
Make Manila UI be installed after Horizon

Recent devstack change [1] made Horizon be installed at later point than it
was. It is inconsistent with our Devstack plugin that now installs Manila UI
earlier than Horizon. So, postpone installation of Manila UI until Horizon
exists and fix gates by this action.

[1] I8bf2ceaf7734c4f7cec68bc05d7cdbae81ef311e

Change-Id: Icb2fc77235cb7f6ec4349dacddf262c3e3be76c2
Closes-Bug: #1532300

commit_message:
Replace deprecated library function os.popen() with subprocess

os.popen() is deprecated since version 2.6. Resolved with use of
subprocess module.

Change-Id: Iea9c0501f46c57d809217912fb0f40eb2bc4f111
Closes-Bug: #1529836

commit_message:
Use assertTrue/False instead of assertEqual(T/F)

The usage of assertEqual(True/False, ***) should be changed
to a meaningful format of assertTrue/False(***).

Closes-Bug: #1512207

Change-Id: I9c611243509bcace99f568c232cc13b728b12838

commit_message:
Add advanced Availability Zone section to networking guide

Change-Id: I9ea73040b4d15f78d529d5652215699841bd3732
Closes-bug: #1519980
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/67/258367/22 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ======================= Using Availability Zone ======================= This page serves as a guide for how to use the "Availability Zone" functionality available in OpenStack Networking as of the Mitaka release. The basics ~~~~~~~~~~ Availability zone groups network nodes. It's defined as attribute of agent on network node. The purpose enable users to specific availability zone with their resources so that the resources get high availability. Use Case -------- Availability zone is used to make network resources high availability. For example, operators group nodes are equipped different power sockets under multiple availability zones and configure scheduling for high availability resources so that they are scheduled on different availability zones. Require extensions ------------------ In order to enable availability zone, core plugin must support ``availability_zone`` extension. Core plugin also must support ``network_availability_zone`` extension to schedule network according to availability zone. ML2 plugin supports it. Router service plugin must support ``router_availability_zone`` extension to schedule router according to availability zone. L3RouterPlugin supports it. .. code-block:: console $ neutron ext-list +---------------------------+-----------------------------------------------+ | alias | name | +---------------------------+-----------------------------------------------+ ... | network_availability_zone | Network Availability Zone | ... | availability_zone | Availability Zone | ... | router_availability_zone | Router Availability Zone | ... +---------------------------+-----------------------------------------------+ Availability Zone of Agents ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ The ``availability_zone`` attribute can be defined in dhcp-agent and l3-agent. In order to define availability zone for each agent, set the value into [agent] section of :file:'etc/neutron.conf' on agent side: [agent] availability_zone = zone-1 To confirm availability zone of agent: .. code-block:: console $ neutron agent-show ca203db1-9f7f-40a7-91aa-4b184886e65d +---------------------+----------------------------------------------------------+ | Field | Value | +---------------------+----------------------------------------------------------+ | admin_state_up | True | | agent_type | DHCP agent | | alive | True | | availability_zone | zone-1 | | binary | neutron-dhcp-agent | | configurations | { | | | "subnets": 0, | | | "dhcp_lease_duration": 86400, | | | "dhcp_driver": "neutron.agent.linux.dhcp.Dnsmasq", | | | "networks": 0, | | | "log_agent_heartbeats": false, | | | "ports": 0 | | | } | | created_at | 2015-12-10 00:30:19 | | description | | | heartbeat_timestamp | 2015-12-10 00:54:09 | | host | mitaka | | id | ca203db1-9f7f-40a7-91aa-4b184886e65d | | started_at | 2015-12-10 00:45:09 | | topic | dhcp_agent | +---------------------+----------------------------------------------------------+ $ $ neutron agent-show 4d8aa289-21eb-4997-86f2-49a884f78d0b +---------------------+---------------------------------------------+ | Field | Value | +---------------------+---------------------------------------------+ | admin_state_up | True | | agent_type | L3 agent | | alive | True | | availability_zone | zone-1 | | binary | neutron-l3-agent | | configurations | { | | | "router_id": "", | | | "agent_mode": "legacy", | | | "gateway_external_network_id": "", | | | "handle_internal_only_routers": true, | | | "routers": 0, | | | "interfaces": 0, | | | "floating_ips": 0, | | | "interface_driver": "openvswitch", | | | "log_agent_heartbeats": false, | | | "external_network_bridge": "br-ex", | | | "ex_gw_ports": 0 | | | } | | created_at | 2015-12-10 00:30:22 | | description | | | heartbeat_timestamp | 2015-12-10 00:54:48 | | host | mitaka | | id | 4d8aa289-21eb-4997-86f2-49a884f78d0b | | started_at | 2015-12-10 00:45:18 | | topic | l3_agent | +---------------------+---------------------------------------------+ Availability Zone Related Addtibutes ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ The following attributes are added into network and router: .. list-table:: :header-rows: 1 :widths: 25 10 10 10 50 * - Attribute name - Access - Required - Input type - Description * - availability_zone_hints - RW(POST only) - No - list of string -  * - availability_zones - RO - N/A - list of string -  Use ``availability_zone_hints`` to specific zones where a resource can be scheduled when creating the resource: .. code-block:: console $ neutron net-create --availability-zone-hint zone-1 --availability-zone-hint zone-2 net1 Created a new network: +---------------------------+--------------------------------------+ | Field | Value | +---------------------------+--------------------------------------+ | admin_state_up | True | | availability_zone_hints | zone-1 | | | zone-2 | | id | 0ef0597c-4aab-4235-8513-bf5d8304fe64 | | mtu | 0 | | name | net1 | | port_security_enabled | True | | provider:network_type | vxlan | | provider:physical_network | | | provider:segmentation_id | 1054 | | router:external | False | | shared | False | | status | ACTIVE | | subnets | | | tenant_id | 32f5512c7b3f47fb8924588ff9ad603b | +---------------------------+--------------------------------------+ .. code-block:: console $ neutron router-create --ha True --availability-zone-hint zone-1 --availability-zone-hint zone-2 router1 Created a new router: +-------------------------+--------------------------------------+ | Field | Value | +-------------------------+--------------------------------------+ | admin_state_up | True | | availability_zone_hints | zone-1 | | | zone-2 | | availability_zones | | | distributed | False | | external_gateway_info | | | ha | True | | id | 272f9be2-e352-4138-92a7-f022449b83a0 | | name | router1 | | routes | | | status | ACTIVE | | tenant_id | 32f5512c7b3f47fb8924588ff9ad603b | +-------------------------+--------------------------------------+ Availability zone is selected from ``default_availability_zones`` in :file:'etc/neutron.conf' if a resource is created without ``availability_zone_hints``: default_availability_zones = zone-1,zone-2 To confirm availability zone defined by system: .. code-block:: console $ neutron availability-zone-list +--------+----------+-----------+ | name | resource | state | +--------+----------+-----------+ | zone-2 | router | available | | zone-1 | router | available | | zone-2 | network | available | | zone-1 | network | available | +--------+----------+-----------+ Look at ``availability_zones`` attribute of each resource to confirm where zone the resource is hosted: .. code-block:: console $ neutron net-show net1 +---------------------------+--------------------------------------+ | Field | Value | +---------------------------+--------------------------------------+ | admin_state_up | True | | availability_zone_hints | zone-1 | | | zone-2 | | availability_zones | zone-1 | | | zone-2 | | id | 0ef0597c-4aab-4235-8513-bf5d8304fe64 | | mtu | 0 | | name | net1 | | port_security_enabled | True | | provider:network_type | vxlan | | provider:physical_network | | | provider:segmentation_id | 1054 | | router:external | False | | shared | False | | status | ACTIVE | | subnets | b24490b9-a3dd-4103-895f-a28aaf2c9bff | | tenant_id | 32f5512c7b3f47fb8924588ff9ad603b | +---------------------------+--------------------------------------+ .. code-block:: console $ neutron router-show router1 +-------------------------+--------------------------------------+ | Field | Value | +-------------------------+--------------------------------------+ | admin_state_up | True | | availability_zone_hints | zone-1 | | | zone-2 | | availability_zones | zone-1 | | | zone-2 | | distributed | False | | external_gateway_info | | | ha | True | | id | 272f9be2-e352-4138-92a7-f022449b83a0 | | name | router1 | | routes | | | status | ACTIVE | | tenant_id | 32f5512c7b3f47fb8924588ff9ad603b | +-------------------------+--------------------------------------+ .. note:: The ``availability_zones`` attribute doesn't have value until the resource is scheduled. Availability Zone Aware Scheduler ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Network Scheduler ----------------- Set ``AZAwareWeightScheduler`` to ``network_scheduler_driver`` in :file:'etc/neutron.conf' so that neutron schedules a network according to availability zone: network_scheduler_driver = neutron.scheduler.dhcp_agent_scheduler.AZAwareWeightScheduler dhcp_load_type = network Neutron schedule the network to one of the agents with selected zone as with ``WeightScheduler``. In the case, scheduler refers ``dhcp_load_type`` as well. Router Scheduler ---------------- Set ``AZLeastRoutersScheduler`` to ``router_scheduler_driver`` in :file:'etc/neutron.conf' so that neutron schedules a router according to availability zone: router_scheduler_driver = neutron.scheduler.l3_agent_scheduler.AZLeastRoutersScheduler Neutron schedule the router to one of the agents with selected zone as with ``LeastRouterScheduler``.

commit_message:
Add window size multipler for resolution options.

This adds a new window size multiplier field to resolution options so
window size can be automatically adjusted to something more reasonable
for a given grouping interval. `second` resolution is capped to 1 day
of data, while `day` resolution now goes back up to 60 days. `hour`
resolution is considered the "base" resolution and remains unchanged.

Change-Id: If8c31ddc2f38b12296be55cddf49b9ba854f6142

commit_message:
Replace deprecated library function os.popen() with subprocess

os.popen() is deprecated since version 2.6. Resolved with use of
subprocess module.
Closes-bug: #1529836

Change-Id: Ibdb8f13462e8416097006e19eb2214425364910e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/octavia refs/changes/39/265539/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import subprocessgit_cmd = ["git", "log", "--pretty=format:'%ad, commit %h'", "--date=local", "-n1"] html_last_updated_fmt = subprocess.Popen(git_cmd, stdout=subprocess.PIPE).communicate()[0]

subject: libvirt:on snapshot delete, use qemu-img to blockRebase if VM is stopped
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-11-09 10:39:00.000000000', 'files': ['nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py', 'nova/tests/unit/virt/libvirt/test_driver.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/aea87902180bebae93680e156a950f00a5f360fd', 'message': 'libvirt:on snapshot delete, use qemu-img to blockRebase if VM is stopped

Libvirt won't do a blockRebase on a domain that is not running. So,
in that case, use "qemu-img rebase" instead.

Note: For now, trying to rebase a network disk using qemu-img raises
a NovaException error because I can't test that it successfully works
for every protocol (gluster, sheepdog, etc) that executes this code
path. I successfully tested this with file-based disk.

Change-Id: I0e6819a6c8dc70b9bd7d1a9c18dc185b4537a3e4
Closes-Bug: #1444806

commit_message:
libvirt:on snapshot delete, use qemu-img to blockRebase if VM is stopped

Libvirt won't do a blockRebase on a domain that is not running. So,
in that case, use "qemu-img rebase" instead.

Note: For now, trying to rebase a network disk using qemu-img raises
a NovaException error because I can't test that it successfully works
for every protocol (gluster, sheepdog, etc) that executes this code
path. I successfully tested this with file-based disk.

Change-Id: I0e6819a6c8dc70b9bd7d1a9c18dc185b4537a3e4
Closes-Bug: #1444806
Closes-Bug: #1465416
(cherry picked from commit 1cf793df252756615dc01a105953346a8747e755)

commit_message:
Fix ha router schedule to dvr agent in compute node

when dvr mode l3-agent run sync_router, neutron server will bind ha router to this agent if ha router hasn't reach max_l3_agents_per_router setting in neutron.conf. This will cause ha router run in computer nodes.

Change-Id: I035dbf3c0a1304507a5e25ef0f075c718d06ba78
Close-Bug: #1526175

commit_message:
Remove py26 support from castellan

As of mitaka, the infra team won't have the resources available to
reasonably test py26, also the oslo team is dropping py26 support
from their libraries. sine we rely on oslo for a lot of our work,
and depend on infra for our CI, we should drop py26 support too.

Change-Id: I4db3fb61038377bc96e47ac160a2da1652901a1b
Related-Bug: #1519510

commit_message:
Move line of code to ensure context and client stay in sync

If the barbican_client.Client() throws an exception, then
self._current_context will not match self._barbican_client.
This fix moves a line of code down to ensure they will match.

Change-Id: I4e6291d98d9b2d37b3d5063b9b20fbb093d254d4
Closes-bug: #1523646
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/castellan refs/changes/23/255323/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self._current_context = context

commit_message:
Drop MANIFEST.in - it's not needed with PBR

Manila uses PBR already - as you can see setup.py:

 setuptools.setup(
     setup_requires=['pbr'],
     pbr=True)

so that, we no longer need MANIFEST.in.

Change-Id: I40794e6eca1daf6c679b1574d2e630e4d78df19b

commit_message:
libvirt: better error for bad live migration flag

Slightly improve the error message we give if the operator configures
the live_migration_flag or block_migration_flag config options with
an invalid migration flag from:

  Live Migration failure: 'module' object has no attribute 'VIR_MIGRATE_FOO_BAR'

to:

  Live Migration failure: Unknown libvirt live migration flag 'VIR_MIGRATE_FOO_BAR'

Change-Id: I2965b369d529e57e00f8bba615303d1a02c216c2
Signed-off-by: Mark McLoughlin <markmc@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/67/264167/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_live_migration_fails_with_invalid_live_migration_flag(self): self.flags(live_migration_flag="VIR_MIGRATE_UNDEFINE_SOURCE, " "VIR_MIGRATE_PEER2PEER, " "VIR_MIGRATE_LIVE, " "VIR_MIGRATE_TUNNELLED, " "VIR_MIGRATE_FOO_BAR", group='libvirt') instance_ref = self.test_instance dom = fakelibvirt.virDomain drvr = libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver(fake.FakeVirtAPI(), False) self.assertRaises(exception.Invalid, drvr._live_migration_operation, self.context, instance_ref, 'dest', False, None, dom)

commit_message:
Replace deprecated library function os.popen() with subprocess

os.popen() is deprecated since version 2.6. Resolved with use of
subprocess module.

Change-Id: I4d0044c110c32f87ac0316a7e665e2bb9ea88813
Partial-Bug: #1529836

subject: Add monitoring dependencies
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-12-01 20:26:03.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-puppet-elements/commit/12de7247e71a4d9b9580945d1c7df747d850a618', 'message': '[operational tools] Add uchiwa component.

Uchiwa is part of the operational toolchain for monitoring an openstack
installation.  Uchiwa is an API/Presentation Layer, which will work with a
monitoring agent/server (sensu) and relay/proxy (rabbitmq).  This patch adds

commit_message:
Add monitoring dependencies

Deploy Sensu and Uchiwa (Sensu dashboard) for a first implementation of
monitoring feature in TripleO.

Uchiwa and Sensu are part of the operational toolchain for monitoring an openstack
installation. Uchiwa is an API/Presentation Layer, which will work with a
monitoring agent/server (sensu) and relay/proxy (rabbitmq).

This patch deploys:
* puppet modules for uchiwa and sensu
* sensu packages on all overcloud nodes (they'll be client of the
  server located on the undercloud)

Change-Id: I603d766ea6ec5104152a715c0fe4ad2f74663cf0

commit_message:
[docs] Fix table elements view on page with list of supported features

Doc file called 'share_back_ends_feature_support_mapping' contains
several table elements separation lines that are inconsistent with
table structure interpreter. So, replace wrong places with correct
ones.

Trivial-fix.

Change-Id: I2ae79911dd49629d5e452acd8e909331b82ef076

commit_message:
devstack: don't enable qos service with the plugin

Require explicit enablement for the service. Enable the service in API
gate job because we have API tests for the service.

Change-Id: Ibdd41eb761b64499a992f49ac0159167c7fb7d79

commit_message:
init: stop include logging class

By including logging class in init.pp, you enforce people to use Hiera
if they want to configure some paramters in init.pp that are not
looked-up by init.pp
We don't want to enforce people to use Hiera so let's stop to import the
class and let people including it in their manifest.

Change-Id: I0bf01d0690fa2604c9a862662f230f3cd57626c4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-aodh refs/changes/52/265452/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Added Keystone and RequestID headers to CORS middleware

CORS middleware's latent configuration feature, new in 3.0.0,
allows adding headers that apply to all valid origins.
This patch adds headers commonly used in openstack to trove's
paste pipeline, so that operators do not have to be aware of
additional configuration magic to ensure that browsers can talk
to the API.

For more information:
http://docs.openstack.org/developer/oslo.middleware/cors.html#configuration-for-pastedeploy

Change-Id: Idf2cd7a0d0d701002f2c1f178475da39ae1a9caf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/03/265403/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: latent_allow_headers = X-Auth-Token, X-Identity-Status, X-Roles, X-Service-Catalog, X-User-Id, X-Tenant-Id, X-OpenStack-Request-ID latent_expose_headers = X-Auth-Token, X-Subject-Token, X-Service-Token, X-OpenStack-Request-ID

subject: KVM: remember IP addresses of nodes
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-01-07 18:51:59.000000000', 'files': ['labs/osbash/tools/repeat-test.sh', 'labs/osbash/lib/osbash/kvm-functions.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/training-labs/commit/6748ee04f9726cd52743ec22e165a6d3ff4fc679', 'message': 'KVM: remember IP addresses of nodes

In the current code, we get the IP address of a VMs first network
interface once via arp; for subsequent requests, we log into the VM via
the management network interface to get the information.

This requires hard-coded assumptions in the host-side code: each VM must
have an active, statically configured interface in a network called
"mgmt".

With this patch, we just store the information we get from arp the first
time around in a text file and retrieve it when needed. We still have to
go through arp only once, but we can drop the assumptions mentioned
above.

Change-Id: Ieb317638b4ddb28d2a54571ad6536efd4511bef7
'}]
commit_message:
KVM: remember IP addresses of nodes

In the current code, we get the IP address of a VMs first network
interface once via arp; for subsequent requests, we log into the VM via
the management network interface to get the information.

This requires hard-coded assumptions in the host-side code: each VM must
have an active, statically configured interface in a network called
"mgmt".

With this patch, we just store the information we get from arp the first
time around in a text file and retrieve it when needed. We still have to
go through arp only once, but we can drop the assumptions mentioned
above.

Change-Id: Ieb317638b4ddb28d2a54571ad6536efd4511bef7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/training-labs refs/changes/19/264919/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: NODE_IP_DB=$LOG_DIR/node_ip.db # Store node name, IP address, and MAC address in text file for later use echo "$mac $ip $node" >> "$NODE_IP_DB" if grep "$node" "$NODE_IP_DB"; then SSH_IP=$(grep " $node$" "$NODE_IP_DB"|awk '{print $2}') return 0 fi echo -e >&2 "${CError:-}ERROR: IP address for $node not found.${CReset:-}" exit 1
deleted_lines: echo "$mac $ip $node" >> "$LOG_DIR/log.ip" # IP address in management network local mgmt_ip="$(source "$CONFIG_DIR/config.$node"; \ get_node_ip_in_network "$node" "mgmt")" echo >&2 "Target node is at $mgmt_ip:$VM_SSH_PORT (mgmt network)." # Wait for VM to respond on management network SSH_IP=$mgmt_ip wait_for_ssh "$VM_SSH_PORT" # Get external IP address from a line like # " inet 192.168.122.232/24 brd [...]" SSH_IP=$(vm_ssh $VM_SSH_PORT "ip addr show eth0" | \ awk -F'[/ ]+' '/inet / { print $3 }') echo >&2 "Target node is at $SSH_IP:$VM_SSH_PORT."

commit_message:
Refactor share metadata tests to use DB

For the moment tests in 'manila.tests.api.v1.test_share_metadata' module
mock all DB requests.
It leads to failures in main code if we use DB-specific things.
So, refactor all tests in that module to use test DB to unblock usage of
DB-specific things.

Change-Id: Ia584e3e6bd02f937df7630a1d09d49c888f77c8f

This patch adds Zaqar Config Reference in RST format to the official
repository.

Currently configuration tables for Zaqar can't be generated fully
automatically with doc-tools, so the patch puts tables for Zaqar to
doc/config-ref-rst/source/tables/manual directory.

To use doc-tools (autogenerate_config_docs) to generate flagmappings
file and tables, current Zaqar repository needs to be modified to make
Zaqar register configuration options in non-lazy way and also not
register configuration options for embedded zaqar-bench tool.
See the example diff:
http://paste.openstack.org/show/mnmSMvsevDb1qjaH9TI7/

Change-Id: I809b7fed10fef3048fabbdd9d867799026a865cb

commit_message:
Add Zaqar to RST Config Reference

This patch adds Zaqar Config Reference in RST format to the official
repository.

Implements: blueprint zaqar-config-ref
Change-Id: I809b7fed10fef3048fabbdd9d867799026a865cb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/05/263405/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. Warning: Do not edit this file. It is automatically generated from the software project's code and your changes will be overwritten. The tool to generate this file lives in openstack-doc-tools repository. Please make any changes needed in the code, then run the autogenerate-config-doc tool from the openstack-doc-tools repository, or ask for help on the documentation mailing list, IRC channel or meeting. .. _zaqar-redis: .. list-table:: Description of Redis configuration options :header-rows: 1 :class: config-ref-table * - Configuration option = Default value - Description * - **[drivers:management_store:redis]** - * - ``max_reconnect_attempts`` = ``10`` - (IntOpt) Maximum number of times to retry an operation that failed due to a redis node failover. * - ``reconnect_sleep`` = ``1.0`` - (FloatOpt) Base sleep interval between attempts to reconnect after a redis node failover. * - ``uri`` = ``redis://127.0.0.1:6379`` - (StrOpt) Redis connection URI, taking one of three forms. For a direct connection to a Redis server, use the form "redis://host[:port][?options]", where port defaults to 6379 if not specified. For an HA master-slave Redis cluster using Redis Sentinel, use the form "redis://host1[:port1][,host2[:port2],...,hostN[:portN]][?options]", where each host specified corresponds to an instance of redis-sentinel. In this form, the name of the Redis master used in the Sentinel configuration must be included in the query string as "master=<name>". Finally, to connect to a local instance of Redis over a unix socket, you may use the form "redis:/path/to/redis.sock[?options]". In all forms, the "socket_timeout" option may be specified in the query string. Its value is given in seconds. If not provided, "socket_timeout" defaults to 0.1 seconds. * - **[drivers:message_store:redis]** - * - ``max_reconnect_attempts`` = ``10`` - (IntOpt) Maximum number of times to retry an operation that failed due to a redis node failover. * - ``reconnect_sleep`` = ``1.0`` - (FloatOpt) Base sleep interval between attempts to reconnect after a redis node failover. * - ``uri`` = ``redis://127.0.0.1:6379`` - (StrOpt) Redis connection URI, taking one of three forms. For a direct connection to a Redis server, use the form "redis://host[:port][?options]", where port defaults to 6379 if not specified. For an HA master-slave Redis cluster using Redis Sentinel, use the form "redis://host1[:port1][,host2[:port2],...,hostN[:portN]][?options]", where each host specified corresponds to an instance of redis-sentinel. In this form, the name of the Redis master used in the Sentinel configuration must be included in the query string as "master=<name>". Finally, to connect to a local instance of Redis over a unix socket, you may use the form "redis:/path/to/redis.sock[?options]". In all forms, the "socket_timeout" option may be specified in the query string. Its value is given in seconds. If not provided, "socket_timeout" defaults to 0.1 seconds.

commit_message:
Fix setup_commit_message for proposal bot

Fix change I80c7f81b0b7f225fbf1e1564239f40b5df8537d9,
I forgot to change a variable name which resulted in
an invalid change ID.

We need to use the variable CHANGE_ID that in the commit message which
is set a few lines above.

Change-Id: I9aeff5c432397f3cb06808066a76afb12f460fd7

deleted_lines: class _new_prop(object): """Create a new property that refers to an old one. For backwards compatibility reasons we need to maintain some attributes of context that should be deprecated. Create a property with a name that points to an otherwise public attribute. """ def __init__(self, old_name): self.old_name = old_name def __get__(self, obj, objtype): return getattr(obj, self.old_name) def __set__(self, obj, val): return setattr(obj, self.old_name, val) # NOTE(jamielennox): for now we store under the old name and reference via # the new name. This is currently easier than changing the __init__ # arguments. In future this should be swapped and the non-_id suffixed # attributes deprecated. user_id = _new_prop('user') project_id = _new_prop('tenant') domain_id = _new_prop('domain') user_domain_id = _new_prop('user_domain') project_domain_id = _new_prop('project_domain')

commit_message:
Implement node_recover in Profile

Add and expose recover support in profile. Implements are based on
REBUILD and RECREATE. It will be extended in future with support
from openstacksdk.

Implements: blueprint support-health-management

Change-Id: I5d6e5fe17cf5ac2ddff0fb1ff62f480acf24b2ac
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/senlin refs/changes/33/262933/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def recover_object(cls, ctx, obj): profile = cls.load(ctx, obj.profile_id) return profile.do_recover(obj) @classmethod def do_recover(self, obj): '''For subclass to override.''' return NotImplemented

commit_message:
Change assertTrue(isinstance()) by optimal assert

Some of tests use different method of assertTrue(isinstance(A, B)) or
assertEqual(type(A), B). The correct way is to use assertIsInstance(A,
B) provided by testtools.

Change-Id: I9053c9deaa71ee12e10db73b19250b3a32f3d93c
Closes-bug: #1268480

commit_message:
Update the file for IPv4-only or IPv6-only network

Clean the file by making both IP versions independent, including when
using LXC containers.

Change-Id: Iecc8184d6dac0d0dec1e88763f2c10367fb1b158
Closes-Bug:#1355171

commit_message:
remove python 2.6 trove classifier

OpenStack projects are no longer being tested under Python 2.6, so
remove the trove classifier implying that this project supports 2.6.

Change-Id: Ie8233fe674eb856d62bc7610864ef2f641bf6b47
(cherry picked from commit 0eacf5d53b1c7f51ee84e5761d93f544b64e56ed)

subject: Don't load deleted instances
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-01-07 14:30:34.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/unit/scheduler/test_host_manager.py', 'nova/scheduler/host_manager.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/7c1f1af2e23494e3424cfc105509fd2f168e06ca', 'message': "Don't load deleted instances

When the HostManager starts up, it loads the instance information for
all of the compute nodes. The call it uses, though, includes the records
for deleted instances, which are not needed, and which can cause
performance issues for large deployments. This patch adds a filter on
deleted records.

Closes-bug: 1524421

commit_message:
Don't load deleted instances

When the HostManager starts up, it loads the instance information for
all of the compute nodes. The call it uses, though, includes the records
for deleted instances, which are not needed, and which can cause
performance issues for large deployments. This patch adds a filter on
deleted records.

Closes-bug: 1524421

Change-Id: I404b6baa5504316f447d9c504132183198ff689e
(cherry picked from commit 3d6fac8dea940b62e88f239c5615acc500b74f05)

is_volume_backed_instance() assumed from old times, that if image_ref
is not set, the instance is always volume backed.  This is not true
anymore, since block device mappings can also reference images as

Change-Id: Ie83d8d8154d372991fb37dae0def37e3f4583090

(cherry picked from commit db184423e512aff9653d74a3d3bcfc6c80b23403)

commit_message:
Fix is_volume_backed_instance() for unset image_ref

is_volume_backed_instance() assumed from old times, that if image_ref
is not set, the instance is always volume backed.  This is not true
anymore, since block device mappings can also reference images as
source.  This fix adapts the test cases and function accordingly.

Change-Id: Ie83d8d8154d372991fb37dae0def37e3f4583090
Closes-Bug: #1501851
(cherry picked from commit db184423e512aff9653d74a3d3bcfc6c80b23403)

deleted_lines: if not instance.image_ref: return True if not root_bdm: return False return root_bdm.is_volume

subject: Refresh stale volume BDMs in terminate_connection
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-12-16 22:40:52.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/unit/compute/test_compute_mgr.py', 'nova/tests/unit/compute/test_compute.py', 'nova/compute/manager.py', 'nova/virt/block_device.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/288c87f531d8ffbaeae3923335077b1968174a22', 'message': "Refresh stale volume BDMs in terminate_connection

NOTE(mriedem): This is a two-part change that is squashed for stable,
where the second change basically moves the code from the first change
up a level to actually fix the bug in nova, else it was only partially
fixed.

--

Make sure bdm.volume_id is set after auto-creating volumes

The test_create_ebs_image_and_check_boot test in Tempest does the
following:

1. create volume1 from an image
2. boot server1 from volume1 with delete_on_termination=True and wait
   for the server to be ACTIVE
3. create snapshot from server1 (creates image and volume snapshots)
4. delete server1
5. create server2 from the image snapshot (don't wait for it to be
   ACTIVE - this auto-creates volume2 from the volume snapshot in
   cinder and attaches server2 to it)
6. delete server2 (could still be building/attaching volumes in the
   background)
7. cleanup

There is a race when booting server2, which creates and attaches
volume2, and deleting server2 before it's active.

The volume attach completes and updates the bdm.volume_id in the DB before
we get to _shutdown_instance, but after the delete request is in the API.
The compute API gets potentially stale BDMs and passes those over RPC to
the compute. So we add a check in _shutdown_instance to see if we have
potentially stale volume BDMs and refresh that list if so.

The instance.uuid locks in build_and_run_instance and terminate_instance
create the mutex on the compute host such that the bdm.volume_id should
be set in the database after the volume attach and before terminate_instance
gets the lock. The bdm.volume_id could still be None in _shutdown_instance
if the volume create fails, but we don't have anything to teardown in cinder
in that case anyway.

In the case of the race bug, deleting the volume snapshot in cinder fails
because volume2 was never deleted by nova, so the test fails in
teardown. Note that there is still potential for a race here, this does
not eliminate it, but should narrow the race window.

This also cleans up the logging in attach_block_devices since there
may not be a volume_id at that point (depending on bdm.source_type).

Conflicts:
        nova/compute/manager.py

NOTE(mriedem): The conflict is due to 48a07fe48 not being in liberty.

Closes-Bug: #1464259

Change-Id: Ib60d60a5af35be89ad8afbcf44fcffe0b0ce2876
(cherry picked from commit 4f2a46987cf705d5dea84e97ef2006342cc5d9c4)

*** This is the 2nd commit message:

Refresh stale volume BDMs in terminate_connection

Change Ib60d60a5af35be89ad8afbcf44fcffe0b0ce2876 meant
to address a race in deleting an instance while booting from
volume such that the BDMs passed to terminate_instance from
the API were stale (no volume_id set yet in the database).

Without the volume_id, _shutdown_instance can't detach the
volumes and _cleanup_volumes can't delete them.

The change fixed the race in _shutdown_instance by refreshing
the BDM list if necessary, but it didn't fix the problem of
deleting the volumes in _cleanup_volumes, which is still
getting a stale list of BDMs from the compute API.

This moves the refresh BDM logic to the top-level method
terminate_instance so that the refreshed BDMs are passed
to both _shutdown_instance and _cleanup_volumes.

There is some cleanup that can be done with
_delete_instance but since we'd like to backport this change
and the previous one, the cleanup is left for a later patch.

Conflicts:
        nova/compute/manager.py
        nova/tests/unit/compute/test_compute_mgr.py

NOTE(mriedem): The manager.py conflict is due to the timer() usage
not being in liberty. The test_compute_mgr.py conflict is due to
test_reset_reloads_rpcapi not being in liberty.

Change-Id: Ib0980a92ebdfa9c83496cd29bfea47fc42d538c5
Closes-Bug: #1464259
(cherry picked from commit e8693e995daae1ed395e6f0d895674d86b76b4c2)
"}]
commit_message:
Refresh stale volume BDMs in terminate_connection

NOTE(mriedem): This is a two-part change that is squashed for stable,
where the second change basically moves the code from the first change
up a level to actually fix the bug in nova, else it was only partially
fixed.

--

Make sure bdm.volume_id is set after auto-creating volumes

The test_create_ebs_image_and_check_boot test in Tempest does the
following:

1. create volume1 from an image
2. boot server1 from volume1 with delete_on_termination=True and wait
   for the server to be ACTIVE
3. create snapshot from server1 (creates image and volume snapshots)
4. delete server1
5. create server2 from the image snapshot (don't wait for it to be
   ACTIVE - this auto-creates volume2 from the volume snapshot in
   cinder and attaches server2 to it)
6. delete server2 (could still be building/attaching volumes in the
   background)
7. cleanup

There is a race when booting server2, which creates and attaches
volume2, and deleting server2 before it's active.

The volume attach completes and updates the bdm.volume_id in the DB before
we get to _shutdown_instance, but after the delete request is in the API.
The compute API gets potentially stale BDMs and passes those over RPC to
the compute. So we add a check in _shutdown_instance to see if we have
potentially stale volume BDMs and refresh that list if so.

The instance.uuid locks in build_and_run_instance and terminate_instance
create the mutex on the compute host such that the bdm.volume_id should
be set in the database after the volume attach and before terminate_instance
gets the lock. The bdm.volume_id could still be None in _shutdown_instance
if the volume create fails, but we don't have anything to teardown in cinder
in that case anyway.

In the case of the race bug, deleting the volume snapshot in cinder fails
because volume2 was never deleted by nova, so the test fails in
teardown. Note that there is still potential for a race here, this does
not eliminate it, but should narrow the race window.

This also cleans up the logging in attach_block_devices since there
may not be a volume_id at that point (depending on bdm.source_type).

Conflicts:
        nova/compute/manager.py

NOTE(mriedem): The conflict is due to 48a07fe48 not being in liberty.

Closes-Bug: #1464259

Change-Id: Ib60d60a5af35be89ad8afbcf44fcffe0b0ce2876
(cherry picked from commit 4f2a46987cf705d5dea84e97ef2006342cc5d9c4)

*** This is the 2nd commit message:

Refresh stale volume BDMs in terminate_connection

Change Ib60d60a5af35be89ad8afbcf44fcffe0b0ce2876 meant
to address a race in deleting an instance while booting from
volume such that the BDMs passed to terminate_instance from
the API were stale (no volume_id set yet in the database).

Without the volume_id, _shutdown_instance can't detach the
volumes and _cleanup_volumes can't delete them.

The change fixed the race in _shutdown_instance by refreshing
the BDM list if necessary, but it didn't fix the problem of
deleting the volumes in _cleanup_volumes, which is still
getting a stale list of BDMs from the compute API.

This moves the refresh BDM logic to the top-level method
terminate_instance so that the refreshed BDMs are passed
to both _shutdown_instance and _cleanup_volumes.

There is some cleanup that can be done with
_delete_instance but since we'd like to backport this change
and the previous one, the cleanup is left for a later patch.

Conflicts:
        nova/compute/manager.py
        nova/tests/unit/compute/test_compute_mgr.py

NOTE(mriedem): The manager.py conflict is due to the timer() usage
not being in liberty. The test_compute_mgr.py conflict is due to
test_reset_reloads_rpcapi not being in liberty.

Change-Id: Ib0980a92ebdfa9c83496cd29bfea47fc42d538c5
Closes-Bug: #1464259
(cherry picked from commit e8693e995daae1ed395e6f0d895674d86b76b4c2)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/95/258695/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if bdm.get('volume_id'): LOG.info(_LI('Booting with volume %(volume_id)s at ' '%(mountpoint)s'), {'volume_id': bdm.volume_id, 'mountpoint': bdm['mount_device']}, context=context, instance=instance) elif bdm.get('snapshot_id'): LOG.info(_LI('Booting with volume snapshot %(snapshot_id)s at ' '%(mountpoint)s'), {'snapshot_id': bdm.snapshot_id, 'mountpoint': bdm['mount_device']}, context=context, instance=instance) elif bdm.get('image_id'): LOG.info(_LI('Booting with volume-backed-image %(image_id)s at ' '%(mountpoint)s'), {'image_id': bdm.image_id, 'mountpoint': bdm['mount_device']}, context=context, instance=instance) else: LOG.info(_LI('Booting with blank volume at %(mountpoint)s'), {'mountpoint': bdm['mount_device']}, context=context, instance=instance)
deleted_lines: LOG.info(_LI('Booting with volume %(volume_id)s at %(mountpoint)s'), {'volume_id': bdm.volume_id, 'mountpoint': bdm['mount_device']}, context=context, instance=instance)

commit_message:
Add properties for id attributes

The user, tenant and similar values are ambiguous. Most contexts that
subclass oslo.context already provide some version of this and use the
_id attributes anyway.

Ideally we would deprecate these values in future but for now just
provide the alias.

Change-Id: Ia59bf69eaa83be1904abe835bfee68b785c92c54
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.context refs/changes/21/264021/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class _new_prop(object): """Create a new property that refers to an old one. For backwards compatibility reasons we need to maintain some attributes of context that should be deprecated. Create a property with a name that points to an otherwise public attribute. """ def __init__(self, old_name): self.old_name = old_name def __get__(self, obj, objtype): return getattr(obj, self.old_name) def __set__(self, obj, val): return setattr(obj, self.old_name, val) # NOTE(jamielennox): for now we store under the old name and reference via # the new name. This is currently easier than changing the __init__ # arguments. In future this should be swapped and the non-_id suffixed # attributes deprecated. user_id = _new_prop('user') project_id = _new_prop('tenant') domain_id = _new_prop('domain') user_domain_id = _new_prop('user_domain') project_domain_id = _new_prop('project_domain')

subject: storage: round back from_timestamp in get_measures()
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-12-02 17:13:04.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/gnocchi/commit/e2d7f4cb7b983daf95f087b809c57b61273ec3f1', 'message': 'storage: round back from_timestamp in get_measures()

This makes sure that if a user request "2014-01-01 12:23" and we have
("2014-01-01 12:20", 300), we do return this too.

This avoids getting 0 point in the API request when the granularity is
larger than the timespan requested.

commit_message:
storage: round back from_timestamp in get_measures()

This makes sure that if a user request "2014-01-01 12:23" and we have
("2014-01-01 12:20", 300), we do return this too.

This avoids getting 0 point in the API request when the granularity is
larger than the timespan requested.

Change-Id: Id7c97308043419555514287df83c3f7cd96cca26
Closes-Bug: #1520322
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/gnocchi refs/changes/25/252525/18 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
carbonara: serialize time period in seconds

It's better than using custom pandas rule codes.
Our code can still read the old format anyway.

Change-Id: Iae9b3485a32dc98b5bef6128ac6386529aa9705f

commit_message:
DVR: Rename dvr_vmarp_table_update

This dvr_vmarp_table_update is not only used to update
the arp entry for the VM ports, but also for other
DVR service ports.

So the function name is kind of misleading and hence
changing it to an appropriate name that fits its function.

Change-Id: I6d5b0b717dcff964a514c83b0cd60b044411f0db

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-01-05 05:55:15.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/unit/api/openstack/compute/test_scheduler_hints.py', 'nova/api/openstack/compute/schemas/scheduler_hints.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/9d47930c8d131b807cbb7f8392435ba54ff45b3c', 'message': "Make scheduler_hints schema allow list of id

That is backward incompatibile issue.
This patch fixes this issue.

NOTE: Tempest patch Ib3365ac2783a0578c7a1a1e72d9b6c9cfea340f5
      is for reproducing this problem on the gate.
      After this fixing, the Tempest patch can be merged and
      we will be able to block this problem.

Change-Id: I1de7d184c590e84ab1b38880c8d784d38c37b820

commit_message:
Make scheduler_hints schema allow list of id

Nova v2.0 API allows a list of server_id, and the corresponding
filter handles it. However, Nova v2.1 API doesn't do that now.
That is backward incompatibile issue.
This patch fixes this issue.

NOTE: Tempest patch Ib3365ac2783a0578c7a1a1e72d9b6c9cfea340f5
      is for reproducing this problem on the gate.
      After this fixing, the Tempest patch can be merged and
      we will be able to block this problem.

Change-Id: I1de7d184c590e84ab1b38880c8d784d38c37b820
Closes-Bug: #1521928
(cherry picked from commit 2841dd3de96792bd9172115945b5ffa5a1fe7c31)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/67/263567/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 'oneOf': [ { 'type': 'string', 'format': 'uuid' }, { 'type': 'array', 'items': parameter_types.server_id } ]

commit_message:
carbonara: deprecate TimeSerieArchive

This patches deprecates TimeSerieArchive in favor of storing each
AggregatedTimeSerie individually. This reduces the size of things to
store a lot more and allow to parallelize more their retrieval and
storage, improving speed and efficiency.

Blueprint: carbonara-archive-split
Change-Id: I8d7f3c13c84d45b298ca053d839e8f783b0a0355
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/gnocchi refs/changes/05/240905/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _build_metric_dir(self, metric): return os.path.join(self.basepath, str(metric.id)) def _build_metric_path(self, metric, aggregation, granularity=None): path = os.path.join(self._build_metric_dir(metric), aggregation) if granularity: return os.path.join(path, granularity) path = self._build_metric_dir(metric) def _store_metric_measures(self, metric, aggregation, granularity, data): os.rename(tmpfile.name, self._build_metric_path( metric, aggregation, granularity)) path = self._build_metric_dir(metric) def _get_measures(self, metric, aggregation, granularity): path = self._build_metric_path(metric, aggregation, granularity) if os.path.exists(self._build_metric_path(metric, aggregation)): raise storage.GranularityDoesNotExist(metric, granularity) if os.path.exists(self._build_metric_dir(metric)): raise storage.MetricDoesNotExist(metric)
deleted_lines: def _build_metric_path(self, metric, aggregation=None): path = os.path.join(self.basepath, str(metric.id)) if aggregation: return os.path.join(path, aggregation) path = self._build_metric_path(metric) def _store_metric_measures(self, metric, aggregation, data): os.rename(tmpfile.name, self._build_metric_path(metric, aggregation)) path = self._build_metric_path(metric) def _get_measures(self, metric, aggregation): path = self._build_metric_path(metric, aggregation) if os.path.exists(self._build_metric_path(metric)): else: raise storage.MetricDoesNotExist(metric)

commit_message:
enable isotime for exceptions

Change Id4754c18935940cc7c738e4a91880267fdeb808f only added isotime to
the formatting for regular log messages, and not exceptions. This change
adds support for the isotime variable in the log prefix string for
tracebacks.

Change-Id: I7203839a2366692e7d54597eacadb17ee24a1f0a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.log refs/changes/53/263453/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @mock.patch("datetime.datetime", get_fake_datetime( datetime.datetime(2015, 12, 16, 13, 54, 26, 517893))) @mock.patch("dateutil.tz.tzlocal", new=mock.Mock(return_value=tz.tzutc())) def test_rfc5424_isotime_format(self): self.config( logging_default_format_string="%(isotime)s %(message)s", logging_exception_prefix="%(isotime)s ", ) product_name = 'somename' exc_log = log.getLogger(product_name) self._add_handler_with_cleanup(exc_log) excepthook = log._create_logging_excepthook(product_name) try: raise Exception('Some error happened') except Exception: excepthook(*sys.exc_info()) expected_string = ("2015-12-16T13:54:26.517893+00:00 " "Exception: Some error happened") self.assertIn(expected_string, self.stream.getvalue())

commit_message:
Notify related services on config file change

Adds service restarts for the following:
account-reaper, container-updater, object-updater,
container-sync, (account/container/object)-auditor.
Each will now be reloaded if their related config file
is updated.

Change-Id: I546bba253bbd0fe890fb77bb9a9f1e632fea242c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-swift refs/changes/64/265064/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: notify => Service["swift-${type}-server", "swift-${type}-replicator", "swift-${type}-auditor"],

commit_message:
Use identity_uri and auth_uri by default

Drop old auth_ parameters that were deprecated, to use by default
identity_uri and auth_uri.

Also deprecate auth_version which has no effect when using identity_uri
and auth_uri.

It keeps default values from before.
Closes-Bug: #1528963

Change-Id: I624ee69268ceaf9adf075509c5f2a5359aef1ff1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-ironic refs/changes/99/262799/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Defaults to 'http://127.0.0.1:5000/'.# Defaults to 'http://127.0.0.1:35357/'.# (optional) DEPRECATED. 'keystone_authtoken/auth_uri': value => $auth_uri; 'keystone_authtoken/identity_uri': value => $identity_uri; 'neutron/url': value => $neutron_url;

Prefix to prepend at the beginning of the keystone path # Defaults to false# (optional) API version of the admin Identity API endpoint $auth_uri = false, $identity_uri = false, $auth_version = false, $neutron_url = false, $auth_host = '127.0.0.1', $auth_port = '35357', $auth_protocol = 'http', $auth_admin_prefix = false, if $neutron_url { ironic_config { 'neutron/url': value => $neutron_url; } } else { ironic_config { 'neutron/url': value => "${auth_protocol}://${auth_host}:9696/"; } } if $auth_uri { ironic_config { 'keystone_authtoken/auth_uri': value => $auth_uri; } } else { ironic_config { 'keystone_authtoken/auth_uri': value => "${auth_protocol}://${auth_host}:5000/"; } } if $identity_uri { ironic_config { 'keystone_authtoken/identity_uri': value => $identity_uri; } } else { ironic_config { 'keystone_authtoken/identity_uri': ensure => absent; } } if $auth_version { ironic_config { 'keystone_authtoken/auth_version': value => $auth_version; } } else { ironic_config { 'keystone_authtoken/auth_version': ensure => absent; } } # if both auth_uri and identity_uri are set we skip these deprecated settings entirely if !$auth_uri or !$identity_uri { if $auth_host { warning('The auth_host parameter is deprecated. Please use auth_uri and identity_uri instead.') ironic_config { 'keystone_authtoken/auth_host': value => $auth_host; } } else { ironic_config { 'keystone_authtoken/auth_host': ensure => absent; } } if $auth_port { warning('The auth_port parameter is deprecated. Please use auth_uri and identity_uri instead.') ironic_config { 'keystone_authtoken/auth_port': value => $auth_port; } } else { ironic_config { 'keystone_authtoken/auth_port': ensure => absent; } } if $auth_protocol { warning('The auth_protocol parameter is deprecated. Please use auth_uri and identity_uri instead.') ironic_config { 'keystone_authtoken/auth_protocol': value => $auth_protocol; } } else { ironic_config { 'keystone_authtoken/auth_protocol': ensure => absent; } } if $auth_admin_prefix { warning('The auth_admin_prefix parameter is deprecated. Please use auth_uri and identity_uri instead.') validate_re($auth_admin_prefix, '^(/.+[^/])?$') ironic_config { 'keystone_authtoken/auth_admin_prefix': value => $auth_admin_prefix; } } else { ironic_config { 'keystone_authtoken/auth_admin_prefix': ensure => absent; } } } else { ironic_config { 'keystone_authtoken/auth_host': ensure => absent; 'keystone_authtoken/auth_port': ensure => absent; 'keystone_authtoken/auth_protocol': ensure => absent; 'keystone_authtoken/auth_admin_prefix': ensure => absent; }

commit_message:
Add tenant ID to to port object

Following patch 3082949cffeefd7ef0dcc3f63f235ce597539ef3 in neutron
tenant ID is retrieved from the port object and
not from the context, add the tenant id to the DHCP and Router port
creation to support Neutron main branch changes.

Change-Id: I510d8f27e5b49634e3a41d4161e5a061ce33df91

commit_message:
Add rabbit_ha_queues option

There are two ways for setting up RabbitMQ HA:

 1. Configure $rabbit_hosts to multi rabbit hosts.
 2. Setting up a loadbalancer in front of RabbitMQ cluster,
    provide a unique address in $rabbit_host

In current, rabbit_ha_queues option is controled by rabbit_hosts
if conditional statement. When users try the second method:
changing rabbit_ha_queues to true. If they don't set rabbit_hosts,
then current logic will not work.

This patch is aim to add an rabbit_ha_queues option, set it to undef
by default for forward compatbility.

Change-Id: I9f61c113b41cb00f7f95e80e2cabe1641aed74e7
Close-Bug: #1485287
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-glance refs/changes/00/215500/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: :rabbit_password => 'pass', :rabbit_userid => 'guest3', :rabbit_hosts => ['nonlocalhost3:5673', 'nonlocalhost4:5673'] describe 'a single rabbit_host with enable ha queues' do let :params do { :rabbit_password => 'pass', :rabbit_userid => 'guest3', :rabbit_ha_queues => true, } end it 'should contain rabbit_ha_queues' do is_expected.to contain_glance_api_config('oslo_messaging_rabbit/rabbit_ha_queues').with_value('true') end end

commit_message:
Fix "health_monitor" object were mis-typed as "healthmonitor" in sample jason file.

According to the Request&Response parameters desciption the object name should be "health_monitor"
http://developer.openstack.org/api-ref-networking-v2-ext.html#createHealthMonitorv2
http://developer.openstack.org/api-ref-networking-v2-ext.html#createHealthMonitor

Change-Id: I084c84a3192742bba65a932b70178a642519285f
Closes-Bug: #1530763

commit_message:
Added Keystone and RequestID headers to CORS middleware

CORS middleware's latent configuration feature, new in 3.0.0,
allows adding headers that apply to all valid origins.
This patch adds headers commonly used in openstack to sahara's paste
pipeline, so that operators do not have to be aware of additional
configuration magic to ensure that browsers can talk to the API.

Change-Id: Ibf89e69f6e9a747043c6d79e20805f66a9c7aefa
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara refs/changes/88/265388/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: latent_allow_headers = X-Auth-Token, X-Identity-Status, X-Roles, X-Service-Catalog, X-User-Id, X-Tenant-Id, X-OpenStack-Request-ID latent_expose_headers = X-Auth-Token, X-Subject-Token, X-Service-Token, X-OpenStack-Request-ID

added_lines: - (StrOpt) A range of TCP ports a guest can use for its backend. Each instance which gets created will use one port out of this range. If the range is not big enough to provide another port for a new instance, this instance won't get launched. Possible values: Each string which passes the regex ``\d+:\d+`` For example ``10000:20000``. Be sure that the first port number is lower than the second port number. Assign admin role for admin user on default domain

This patch adds an admin role assignment for the admin user on
the default domain as part of the Keystone configuration stage.

Closes-Bug: #1494081

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-10-16 10:51:56.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/ceebe68ccaba09c3378404eff68b7fbb70ea1a4a', 'message': 'DVR: notify specific agent when creating floating ip

Currently when floating ip is created, a lot of useless action
is happening: floating ip router is scheduled, all l3 agents where
router is scheduled are notified about router update, all agents
request full router info from server. All this becomes a big
performance problem at scale with lots of compute nodes.

In fact on (associated) Floating IP creation we really need
to notify specific l3 agent on compute node where associated
VM port is located and do not need to schedule router and
bother other agents where rourter is scheduled. This should
significally decrease unneeded load on neutron server at scale.

Partial-Bug: #1486828
Change-Id: I0cbe8c51c3714e6cbdc48ca37135b783f8014905
(cherry picked from commit 865dc46bc5687813c746ad490be6f534f46f518d)

Partial-Bug: #1486828
Change-Id: I0cbe8c51c3714e6cbdc48ca37135b783f8014905
(cherry picked from commit 865dc46bc5687813c746ad490be6f534f46f518d)

=========

DVR: Notify specific agent when update floatingip

The L3 agent was determined when update floatingip.
So notify the specific agent rather than notify all agents.
This will save some RPC resources. This is only for DVR routers.
Legacy and HA routers notify only the relevant agents.

This reproposes commit 52e91f48f2327b47f126893f9cb12f153380a9a6
which was reverted by commit a2f7e0343a147a30a637af4e1cb9a866f557e87d
because of Ironic gate failures.
Now the patch preserves original behavior for legacy routers and
should not break Ironic tests.

Partial-Bug: #1486828
Related-Bug: #1507602
Change-Id: I4ef7a69ad033b979ea0e29620a4febfe5e0c30dd
(cherry picked from commit 8a51ddf3be6445a49c53b7a9ef80123cf0e7c033)

=========

Two patches are squashed because the first one introduced a regression
when some notifications were not sent in particular scenarios.

Change-Id: I0cbe8c51c3714e6cbdc48ca37135b783f8014905

because of Ironic gate failures.
Now the patch preserves original behavior for legacy routers and

Partial-Bug: #1486828
Related-Bug: #1507602

=========

Use admin context when requesting floating ip's router info

Currently it is possible for admin to create router and add any
tenant subnet to it, thus connecting the subnet to the external
network. In this case tenant user can assign floating ips to its
VMs though it does not own the router.
For proper notification we need to get router info using admin
context.

Closes-Bug: #1507602
Change-Id: I17330ddca577d15e42c13ef0af96d56e6f20abd7

=========

Three patches are squashed because the first one introduced a regression
when some notifications were not sent in particular scenarios. Two
consequent patches target the regression.

commit_message:
DVR: notify specific agent when creating floating ip

Currently when floating ip is created, a lot of useless action
is happening: floating ip router is scheduled, all l3 agents where
router is scheduled are notified about router update, all agents
request full router info from server. All this becomes a big
performance problem at scale with lots of compute nodes.

In fact on (associated) Floating IP creation we really need
to notify specific l3 agent on compute node where associated
VM port is located and do not need to schedule router and
bother other agents where rourter is scheduled. This should
significally decrease unneeded load on neutron server at scale.

Partial-Bug: #1486828
Change-Id: I0cbe8c51c3714e6cbdc48ca37135b783f8014905
(cherry picked from commit 865dc46bc5687813c746ad490be6f534f46f518d)

=========

DVR: Notify specific agent when update floatingip

The L3 agent was determined when update floatingip.
So notify the specific agent rather than notify all agents.
This will save some RPC resources. This is only for DVR routers.
Legacy and HA routers notify only the relevant agents.

This reproposes commit 52e91f48f2327b47f126893f9cb12f153380a9a6
which was reverted by commit a2f7e0343a147a30a637af4e1cb9a866f557e87d
because of Ironic gate failures.
Now the patch preserves original behavior for legacy routers and
should not break Ironic tests.

Partial-Bug: #1486828
Related-Bug: #1507602
Change-Id: I4ef7a69ad033b979ea0e29620a4febfe5e0c30dd
(cherry picked from commit 8a51ddf3be6445a49c53b7a9ef80123cf0e7c033)

=========

Use admin context when requesting floating ip's router info

Currently it is possible for admin to create router and add any
tenant subnet to it, thus connecting the subnet to the external
network. In this case tenant user can assign floating ips to its
VMs though it does not own the router.
For proper notification we need to get router info using admin
context.

Closes-Bug: #1507602
Change-Id: I17330ddca577d15e42c13ef0af96d56e6f20abd7

=========

Three patches are squashed because the first one introduced a regression
when some notifications were not sent in particular scenarios. Two
consequent patches target the regression.

Change-Id: I0cbe8c51c3714e6cbdc48ca37135b783f8014905

added_lines: def _notification_host(self, context, method, host, **kwargs): cctxt.cast(context, method, **kwargs) self._notification_host(context, 'agent_updated', host, payload={'admin_state_up': admin_state_up}) self._notification_host(context, 'router_removed_from_agent', host, payload={'router_id': router_id}) self._notification_host(context, 'router_added_to_agent', host, payload=router_ids) def routers_updated_on_host(self, context, router_ids, host): self._notification_host(context, 'routers_updated', host, routers=router_ids)
deleted_lines: def _notification_host(self, context, method, payload, host): cctxt.cast(context, method, payload=payload) self._notification_host(context, 'agent_updated', {'admin_state_up': admin_state_up}, host) self._notification_host(context, 'router_removed_from_agent', {'router_id': router_id}, host) self._notification_host(context, 'router_added_to_agent', router_ids, host)

commit_message:
Do not send project_id to Octavia API on PUTs

The octavia driver was sending project_id to the Octavia API on PUTs.  Since
the Octavia API does not accept project_id on PUTs, it fails.  The solution is
to just send project_id on POSTs and not PUTs.

Closes-Bug: #1531985
Change-Id: Ia9aad2b565d1f40f4e6041dac7565e36331b031a
